maybeIfYouGetToTheTestThatHasTheInterminiblyLongName_ThatIsAnIndicationThatThereIsEntirelyTooMuchToTestInThatOneTestClass?


-------------- Original message -------------- 
From: David Saff <saff@...> 
jason r tibbetts wrote:
> On that note, what conventions does everyone here use to name their test
> methods? For this example, mine would look like:
>
> test_push_emptyStack()
> test_push_stackWith1Element()
> test_push_fullStack()
> test_push_nullElement()

I've lately tended toward declarative sentences where possible in my own 
work, such as

testPushAddsAnElementToEmptyStack
testPushAddWorksOnStackWithOneElement // ?
@Test pushThrowsExceptionOnFullStack
@Test pushRejectsNullElement

Advantages:

1) It makes me think harder about what I'm testing.  For example, why am 
I testing a stack with one element?  Just to make sure that a stack can 
hold two elements?  In that case, I might call it 
testStackCanHoldTwoElements, since it's not really about the push element.

2) I don't have to necessarily have a method already in mind when I name 
the test.

Disadvantages:

1) When I get lazy (not that this is at all common.  :-) ), you might 
see terrible names like @Test pushIsCorrect or testPushWorks, which are 
very questionably better than testPush.  On the other hand, the terrible 
names make me more likely to think of better names, which can make me 
think more about better tests.

2) 
CamelCaseIsNotActuallyTheEasiestThingToRead_whichMakesMeWonderIfSomeSortOfDescriptiveFreetextAnnotationWouldBeBetter(WikisEventuallyDidThis).

Share and Enjoy,

    David Saff
